Title: Stupid TV, Be More Funny: How the Golden Era of The Simpsons Changed Television—and America—Forever
Author: Alan Siegel

Title: The Intelligent Investor
Author: Benjamin Graham

Title: Apple in China: The Capture of the World's Greatest Company
Author: Patrick  McGee

Title: Government Gangsters: The Deep State, the Truth, and the Battle for Our Democracy
Author: Kash Patel

Title: Wasteland: The Secret World of Waste and the Urgent Search for a Cleaner Future
Author: Oliver Franklin-Wallis

Title: Cobalt Red: How the Blood of the Congo Powers Our Lives
Author: Siddharth Kara

Title: The Trading Game: A Confession
Author: Gary  Stevenson

Title: Nexus: A Brief History of Information Networks from the Stone Age to AI
Author: Yuval Noah Harari

Title: How Big Things Get Done: The Surprising Factors That Determine the Fate of Every Project, from Home Renovations to Space Exploration and Everything In Between
Author: Bent Flyvbjerg

Title: Thinking In Systems: A Primer
Author: Donella H. Meadows

Title: Stolen Focus: Why You Can't Pay Attention— and How to Think Deeply Again
Author: Johann Hari

Title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
Author: Gabrielle Zevin

Title: The Anthropocene Reviewed: Essays on a Human-Centered Planet
Author: John Green

Title: Material World: The Six Raw Materials That Shape Modern Civilization
Author: Ed Conway

Title: Never Finished: Unshackle Your Mind and Win the War Within
Author: David Goggins

Title: The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer
Author: Siddhartha Mukherjee

Title: Mixed Plate: Chronicles of an All-American Combo – A Hilarious Stand-Up Comedian Memoir of Filipino Heritage and Perseverance
Author: Jo Koy

Title: The Mental Game of Trading: A System for Solving Problems with Greed, Fear, Anger, Confidence, and Discipline
Author: Jared Tendler

Title: Elon Musk
Author: Walter Isaacson
My Review: Not a big fan of Elon, but Isaacson did an incredible job with this book.

Title: Doppelganger: A Trip into the Mirror World
Author: Naomi Klein

Title: Chip War: The Fight for the World's Most Critical Technology
Author: Chris   Miller

Title: Scaling People: Tactics for Management and Company Building
Author: Claire Hughes Johnson

Title: Smoke Gets in Your Eyes & Other Lessons from the Crematory
Author: Caitlin Doughty

Title: Mud, Sweat and Tears
Author: Bear Grylls

Title: Soul Boom: Why We Need a Spiritual Revolution
Author: Rainn Wilson

Title: Build: An Unorthodox Guide to Making Things Worth Making
Author: Tony Fadell

Title: The Office: The Untold Story of the Greatest Sitcom of the 2000s: An Oral History
Author: Andy Greene

Title: Dapper Dan: Made in Harlem
Author: Daniel R. Day

Title: Straight Shooter: A Memoir of Second Chances and First Takes
Author: Stephen A. Smith

Title: Build for Tomorrow: An Action Plan for Embracing Change, Adapting Fast, and Future-Proofing Your Career
Author: Jason  Feifer

Title: Creativity Code
Author: Marcus du Sautoy
My Review: This book could've been a tweet thread. Would not recommend unless you absolutely love the cross between art and AI

Title: The Code Breaker: Jennifer Doudna, Gene Editing, and the Future of the Human Race
Author: Walter Isaacson

Title: Caste: The Origins of Our Discontents
Author: Isabel Wilkerson
My Review:
I was skeptical about the book, and have seen the huge # of Race related books on the market in the past few years thought this would be another one.

The author does an amazing job explaining how US society is not 'race' impacted but 'Caste' impacted, with the comparisons to Nazi Germany and India are spot on across every segment of their society. This book should be mandatory reading in the US, the same way WWII is mandatory in Germany.

Title: Tough: My Journey to True Power
Author: Terry Crews

Title: Blood and Oil: Mohammed bin Salman's Ruthless Quest for Global Power
Author: Bradley Hope

Title: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century
Author: Yuval Noah Harari

Title: How to Be Perfect: The Correct Answer to Every Moral Question
Author: Michael Schur

Title: You Can’t Be Serious
Author: Kal Penn

Title: Sid Meier's Memoir!: A Life in Computer Games
Author: Sid Meier

Title: Mythos: The Greek Myths Retold (Stephen Fry's Great Mythology, #1)
Author: Stephen Fry
My Review: Interesting read. Stephen Fry does a great job with the audio book. Would recommend only if someone has interest already in ancient history or mythology.

Title: The Innovators: How a Group of Hackers, Geniuses and Geeks Created the Digital Revolution
Author: Walter Isaacson

Title: Moneyland: Why Thieves and Crooks Now Rule the World and How To Take It Back
Author: Oliver Bullough
My Review: Entertaining, insightful and engaging.

Title: Maybe You Should Talk to Someone: A Therapist, Her Therapist, and Our Lives Revealed
Author: Lori Gottlieb
My Review: Refreshing and honest look into the work of Therapy. A variety of personal stories, and does a great job to normalize it.

Title: Scale: The Universal Laws of Growth, Innovation, Sustainability, and the Pace of Life in Organisms, Cities, Economies, and Companies
Author: Geoffrey B. West

Title: Atomic Habits: An Easy & Proven Way to Build Good Habits & Break Bad Ones
Author: James Clear

Title: The Cryptopians: Idealism, Greed, Lies, and the Making of the First Big Cryptocurrency Craze
Author: Laura Shin

Title: Will
Author: Will  Smith

Title: Empire of Pain: The Secret History of the Sackler Dynasty
Author: Patrick Radden Keefe
My Review: Didn't know much about the Opioid crisis, but this book is an incredibly detailed look into the family pulling the strings. Having seen their names in museums, the book adds context as to how the family has so much money.

Title: The Premonition: A Pandemic Story
Author: Michael   Lewis

Title: Genius Makers: The Mavericks Who Brought AI to Google, Facebook, and the World
Author: Cade Metz
My Review: Interesting back story inside the world of AI research.

Title: The Cult of We: WeWork, Adam Neumann, and the Great Startup Delusion
Author: Eliot Brown

Title: The World for Sale: Money, Power and the Traders Who Barter the Earth’s Resources
Author: Javier Blas
My Review: The premise may seem boring, but this book brings to late the crazy power and influence commodity traders have in development + developing world. Would recommend as an entertaining ‘non-tech’ industry bio.

Title: No Rules Rules: Netflix and the Culture of Reinvention
Author: Reed Hastings

Title: How to Change Everything: The Young Human's Guide to Protecting the Planet and Each Other
Author: Naomi Klein

Title: Catch and Kill: Lies, Spies, and a Conspiracy to Protect Predators
Author: Ronan Farrow

Title: Yearbook
Author: Seth Rogen
My Review: The audiobook is read by him with cameos by all the other famous folks. Very funny (nsfw) book.

Title: Amazon Unbound: Jeff Bezos and the Invention of a Global Empire
Author: Brad Stone

Title: American Icon: Alan Mulally and the Fight to Save Ford Motor Company
Author: Bryce G. Hoffman
My Review:
I'm not a big fan of the auto industry, but this was genuinely a fascinating insight into the company. Different to insights into startups or tech companies, it was a unique perspective on a brand I had no opinion on or interest in.

Would recommend for anyone who likes company bio's.

Title: The Wal-Mart Effect: How the World's Most Powerful Company Really Works - and How It's Transforming the American Economy
Author: Charles Fishman

Title: The Man Who Solved the Market: How Jim Simons Launched the Quant Revolution
Author: Gregory Zuckerman
My Review: Engaging read. I didn't realize Mercer from Rentec was behind Breitbart and Brexit. Interesting to hear about the background and ripple effects of the crazy amount of money they made.

Title: Tiny Habits: The Small Changes That Change Everything
Author: B.J.  Fogg
My Review: I normally don't like the "self help" category, as they're just one idea rehashed a bunch of times that aren't practical. This was surprisingly good for the genre, where the author recommends super simple steps to make permanent change. Could have been a tad shorter. Would recommend for everyone to read.

Title: How to Avoid a Climate Disaster: The Solutions We Have and the Breakthroughs We Need
Author: Bill  Gates
My Review: This was surprisingly good. Bill lays out a clear state along with our alternatives for reducing carbon emissions. Most options involve step changes in technology for all the verticals that contribute carbon.

Title: Radical Candor: Be a Kickass Boss Without Losing Your Humanity
Author: Kim Malone Scott

Title: Working Backwards: Insights, Stories, and Secrets from Inside Amazon
Author: Colin Bryar
My Review: Interesting book, but too much Kool-Aid and not enough detail on examples outside of what Colin worked on himself. There was probably lots of activity and discussions outside of the PR FAQ process or the lack of slides that made Amazon successful.

Title: Think Again: The Power of Knowing What You Don't Know
Author: Adam M. Grant

Title: Is This Anything?
Author: Jerry Seinfeld

Title: A Promised Land
Author: Barack Obama

Title: The Book of eSports: The Definitive Guide to Competitive Video Games
Author: William Collis
My Review: Good summary and overview of the esports landscape, but lacks much depth about the relationship between the teams, owners and players.

Title: The Infinite Game
Author: Simon Sinek

Title: The Body: A Guide for Occupants
Author: Bill Bryson
My Review: This is one of those books that every human should read. It's basically a quick guide to everything that exists in your body.

Title: The King of Oil: The Secret Lives of Marc Rich
Author: Daniel Ammann

Title: The Autobiography of Malcolm X
Author: Malcolm X
My Review:
I... couldn't read the book. I ended up watching the movie.

Movie was good though

Title: What You Do Is Who You Are: How to Create Your Business Culture
Author: Ben Horowitz

Title: How I Built This: The Unexpected Paths to Success From the World's Most Inspiring Entrepreneurs
Author: Guy Raz

Title: The Culture Code: The Secrets of Highly Successful Groups
Author: Daniel Coyle

Title: Spark: The Revolutionary New Science of Exercise and the Brain
Author: John J. Ratey

Title: Down Girl: The Logic of Misogyny
Author: Kate Manne
My Review: Great book which delivers a direct look into how the patriarchy and misogyny seeps into all aspects of society.

Title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
Author: Matthew Walker
My Review:
This is one of those books everyone in the world should read, regardless of your book preference. Every person sleeps, and should be aware of the crazy impact it has on us.

TLDR - min 7 hours sleep a night for the rest of your life.

Title: Good Economics for Hard Times: Better Answers to Our Biggest Problems
Author: Abhijit V. Banerjee

Title: To Pixar and Beyond: My Unlikely Journey with Steve Jobs to Make Entertainment History
Author: Lawrence Levy
My Review:
Interesting book highlighting the financial side to Pixar's success. Useful to read this right after Bob Igers book about Disney, to see the other side of the coin.

I also think it's important to partner with the creativity Pixar book, as it shows that the business side of a company is just as important for success as the creative product.

Title: Storytelling with Data: A Data Visualization Guide for Business Professionals
Author: Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic

Title: The Ride of a Lifetime: Lessons Learned from 15 Years as CEO of the Walt Disney Company
Author: Robert Iger
My Review:
Two parts stood out for me in this book:

1. All the acquisitions that Iger led (Marvel, Lucasarts, Pixar, 21st Century Fox)
2. The amount of context switching Iger has to do a on a day-to-day basis considering how many different business units Disney is responsible for.

Nothing in this book talks about how Disney operates as a business, which would also be interesting. Most of the "Lessons learned" are quite generic and mainly useful if you're a CEO of a Fortune 500.

Definitely recommended read, but don't expect juicy insights into the inner workings of Disney.

Title: The Shock Doctrine: The Rise of Disaster Capitalism
Author: Naomi Klein
My Review:
Wow. It's as if all the chapters in this book are a prequel to what is happening so far in 2020. The world is currently in a state of complete shock, and it will be interesting to see which corporations and governments take advantage to solidify power into their own hands.

Great read. "No Logo" by Naomi Klein was my first non-fiction/sociology book just under 20 years ago, and this book reminds why I love the genre. Highly recommended

Title: The Spider Network: The Wild Story of a Math Genius, a Gang of Backstabbing Bankers, and One of the Greatest Scams in Financial History
Author: David Enrich
My Review: This was much more boring than anticipated. It's not a fun adventure like Michael Lewis' Flash Boys, this is just about bankers abusing interest rate swaps.

Title: Black Edge: Inside Information, Dirty Money, and the Quest to Bring Down the Most Wanted Man on Wall Street
Author: Sheelah Kolhatkar

Title: Invisible Women: Data Bias in a World Designed for Men
Author: Caroline Criado Pérez
My Review:
Going through life, it's hard to imagine how many things are designed without women in mind. This book goes through examples ranging from health, to technology, to police uniforms, displaying the impact of ignoring women in how things are designed. To top it off, each example in the book is backed by global studies.

This is a must read!

Title: Explosive Growth: A Few Things I Learned While Growing To 100 Million Users - And Losing $78 Million
Author: Cliff Lerner
My Review:
Had some interesting points, but overall it was very much a story about how one company works, then assuming it can be applied to every company.

Also lots of "pro tips" sprinkled throughout, most of which weren't terribly insightful.

Good book if you've never done anything online marketing related.

Title: Super Pumped: The Battle for Uber
Author: Mike Isaac
My Review:
One of the most entertaining books I've read. Sure a lot of it is exaggerated, or taken out of context. But if you're not a fan of SF bro culture, this book double's down on the hate. Great read!

Note: I listened to the Audible which was probably part of the entertainment value. Not sure if the book will have the same level of excitement

Title: That Will Never Work: The Birth of Netflix and the Amazing Life of an Idea
Author: Marc Randolph

Title: Talking to Strangers: What We Should Know About the People We Don't Know
Author: Malcolm Gladwell

Title: Permanent Record
Author: Edward Snowden
My Review: Enjoyable autobiography of Snowden, his life and all the craziness surrounding his Whistleblowing

Title: When Genius Failed: The Rise and Fall of Long-Term Capital Management
Author: Roger Lowenstein
My Review:
The story itself is a classic boom and bust story about a highly leveraged investment firm.

Didn’t find it very engaging. Maybe coming from an investment banking background it would be more relatable. In a world before Billions or Wolf of Wall Street, it might’ve been a more unique story.

Title: The Culture Map: Breaking Through the Invisible Boundaries of Global Business
Author: Erin Meyer

Title: Built to Last: Successful Habits of Visionary Companies
Author: Jim Collins

Title: Straight Talk for Startups: 100 Insider Rules for Beating the Odds--From Mastering the Fundamentals to Selecting Investors, Fundraising, Managing Boards, and Achieving Liquidity
Author: Randy Komisar
My Review:
A great book for anyone wanting to start their own startup from scratch.

It's 100 practical points, all of which are 2-4 pages of content. Perfectly condensed, with enough reading to understand the point before continuing. I wish more business'y books were structured like this.

Title: How to Win Friends & Influence People
Author: Dale Carnegie
My Review: Classic and timeless book about the basics of business. Not usually a fan of old books, but this one was great.

Title: The Bitcoin Standard: The Decentralized Alternative to Central Banking
Author: Saifedean Ammous
My Review:
Excellent book. I loved the first few chapters about the history of money, which led very nicely into why "Sound Money" is so important. Would highly recommend this to anyone who is investigating cryptocurrencies and wants to know what all the fuss is about.

The only thing that was a bit strange (and unnecessary), was the hate in the last chapter towards ETH. Yes the DAO was bad, but why spend so much time hating. Clearly the BTC maximalism kool-aid is strong enough to spill over into an actually published book.

Title: The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power
Author: Daniel Yergin

Title: Principles: Life and Work
Author: Ray Dalio
My Review:
The book is split into three parts:
1. Ray's Life
2. Ray's personal principles
3. Ray's work principles

It was very interesting to hear about both his life and the work principles. The work principles are well articulated and broad enough to relate to multiple industries. I've never had so many 'notes' in a book before, as there is a lot to digest.

This book gives clarity on the often used phrase "Let's take a principled approach". You gotta have clear principles, before you can do that.

Title: The Club: How the English Premier League Became the Wildest, Richest, Most Disruptive Force in Sports
Author: Joshua  Robinson

Title: Original Gangstas: The Untold Story of Dr. Dre, Eazy-E, Ice Cube, Tupac Shakur, and the Birth of West Coast Rap
Author: Ben Westhoff
My Review: Interesting book on the history of west coast rappers from NWA to Tupac’s death. The author writes objectively and has clearly done extensive research.

Title: Total Recall: My Unbelievably True Life Story
Author: Arnold Schwarzenegger
My Review: A lot I didn’t know about Arnie. This book is an interesting insight into the drive and determination of the entrepreneur/actor/governor/bodybuilder. The guy has lived 4 lives in one.

Title: Trillion Dollar Coach: The Leadership Playbook of Silicon Valley's Bill Campbell
Author: Eric Schmidt
My Review: Great story about Bill. Empathy and love go a long way in building strong teams.

Title: The Year Without Pants: WordPress.com and the Future of Work
Author: Scott Berkun

Title: Measure What Matters
Author: John Doerr

Title: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck: A Counterintuitive Approach to Living a Good Life
Author: Mark Manson

Title: Secrets of Sand Hill Road: Venture Capital and How to Get It
Author: Scott Kupor

Title: Becoming
Author: Michelle Obama

Title: Homo Deus: A Brief History of Tomorrow
Author: Yuval Noah Harari
My Review:
Interesting take on the future of humanity. Yuval paints a futuristic vision consisting of Humanism as the religion, and data/machines/algorithms as slowly taking over the word. Most of what he is saying seems to make sense at the surface.

However one fundamental problem I had with the book. Yuval is atheist, which results in him dismissing an individual's higher self or soul when it comes to how society will develop. This seems short sighted, and provides a skewed perspective on how society will develop.

Would recommend to friends, but with the above caveat in mind.

Title: Economics in One Lesson
Author: Henry Hazlitt

Title: A Template for Understanding Big Debt Crises
Author: Ray Dalio

Title: The Quest: Energy, Security, and the Remaking of the Modern World
Author: Daniel Yergin

Title: Born a Crime: Stories From a South African Childhood
Author: Trevor Noah

Title: The Silk Roads: A New History of the World
Author: Peter Frankopan
My Review:
The book seems to basically describe one game of Civ from beginning to end.

In all seriousness it's a fantastic and interesting insight into the Silk Road. From < 1000 BC to modern day, the region has been the focal point for turmoil, conflict and prosperity. Would recommend for anyone remotely interested in history or money.

Title: Strangers in Their Own Land: Anger and Mourning on the American Right
Author: Arlie Russell Hochschild

Title: The Black Swan: The Impact of the Highly Improbable
Author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb

Title: Narconomics: How to Run a Drug Cartel
Author: Tom Wainwright
My Review:
An interesting economists perspective on running a drug cartel, and an objective analysis into the methods of reducing violence associated with them.

It's like a background study guide for anyone interested Narcos.

Title: How to Fail at Almost Everything and Still Win Big: Kind of the Story of My Life
Author: Scott Adams

Title: Skunk Works: A Personal Memoir of My Years at Lockheed
Author: Ben R. Rich
My Review: If you like a detailed history of the various types of stealth fighters created, this is your book!

Title: How the Internet Happened: From Netscape to the iPhone
Author: Brian  McCullough

Title: The Virgin Way: Everything I Know About Leadership
Author: Richard Branson
My Review: Interesting take on leadership from a previous generation. Virgin it seems is like the ‘Google’ or the 80s and 90s. Very progressive and fun place to work.

Title: What If?: Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions
Author: Randall Munroe
My Review: Really fun book to read. Would recommend the paperback as it has comics throughout. Good bedtime story book for older kids as well!

Title: Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup
Author: John Carreyrou
My Review: Fascinating story about deceit in the biotech industry. A bit too detailed for things that aren’t too important to the critical story. I guess the journalist really wanted to show how credible and accurate his sources are.

Title: The Art of Community: Seven Principles for Belonging
Author: Charles H. Vogl
My Review: If you want to start your own religion, these are the 7 steps to make it happen.

Title: The Open Organization: Igniting Passion and Performance
Author: Jim Whitehurst
My Review:
Great book about the COO of Delta, moving to become the CEO of Red Hat. It's a short read, that tells the story of a different type of org.

It's like a practical guide on how to deal with open organisations.

Title: The True Believer: Thoughts on the Nature of Mass Movements
Author: Eric Hoffer

Title: New Power: How Power Works in Our Hyperconnected World—and How to Make It Work for You
Author: Jeremy Heimans

Title: 21 Lessons for the 21st Century
Author: Yuval Noah Harari

Title: The Coming Storm
Author: Michael   Lewis
My Review: A short story about weather. Most interesting part is that Trump has installed private sector people to be responsible for the US weather data. The head of NOAH is trying to restrict open data use in order for AccuWeather to be the exclusive for-profit way of getting weather data.

Title: Genghis Khan and the Making of the Modern World
Author: Jack Weatherford
My Review:
First half was an amazing story about Genghis himself. Amazing person, worth the read

Second half was first about his lineage, his kids and grandkids and how the screwed everything up. Then the last quarter of the book goes through the next 600 years and attributes most inventions in the world to the Mongols. From Algebra to satin, to the spread of the plague, all thanks to the Mongols 🤔. Seems a stretch at times, but interesting nonetheless.

Title: Unbelievable: My Front-Row Seat to the Craziest Campaign in American History
Author: Katy Tur

Title: Authentic Conversations: Moving from Manipulation to Truth and Commitment
Author: Jamie Showkeir

Title: Option B: Facing Adversity, Building Resilience, and Finding Joy
Author: Sheryl Sandberg
My Review: Good for people who are going through a sudden hardship/loss. Will probably re-read at a later date

Title: The Book of Why: The New Science of Cause and Effect
Author: Judea Pearl

Title: The Autobiography of Gucci Mane
Author: Gucci Mane

Title: Give and Take: A Revolutionary Approach to Success
Author: Adam M. Grant
My Review:
Another book that can do with a TL;DR section. Adam brings up a handful of simple concepts (eg the 5 minute favor, or donating 100 hours a week of time is the optimum amount), but then spends page after page providing anecdotal case studies about how it worked for Joe Smith who was kind to someone at work.

Having said that, the book was interesting, but I would highly recommend someone read a summary then decide to read the full book.

Title: The Cluetrain Manifesto: The End of Business as Usual
Author: Rick Levine
Additional Authors: Christopher Locke, Doc Searls, David Weinberger
My Review:
First 1/4 of the anniversary edition is very interesting. For someone to predict community centric organizations on the internet in 2000 is amazing.

Unfortunately the book itself ends up dry, as most of the examples are not relevant.

Title: Antifragile: Things That Gain from Disorder
Author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
My Review:
Interesting and unique concepts about creating antifragile organisations and organisms.

However, I didn't know it was possible to write with such an arrogant and condescending tone as a popular author.

Title: Solve for Happy: Engineer Your Path to Joy
Author: Mo Gawdat
My Review: Warm and fuzzy book, taking a rational approach to life, God and human behaviour

Title: Making the Social World: The Structure of Human Civilization
Author: John Rogers Searle

Title: Algorithms to Live By: The Computer Science of Human Decisions
Author: Brian  Christian

Title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
Author: Yuval Noah Harari

Title: A Life in Parts
Author: Bryan Cranston
My Review: If you're a fan of acting or Breaking Bad, this is a definitely an interesting book. A detailed look at his childhood, acting career and eventually, the main parts of BB. The entire audiobook is narrated by Bryan himself, which makes the boring parts more bearable.

Title: The Launch Pad: Inside Y Combinator, Silicon Valley's Most Exclusive School for Startups
Author: Randall E. Stross

Title: The Internet of Money
Author: Andreas M. Antonopoulos

Title: Elon Musk: Tesla, SpaceX, and the Quest for a Fantastic Future
Author: Ashlee Vance

Title: Work Rules! Lib/E: Insights from Inside Google That Will Transform How You Live and Lead
Author: Laszlo Bock

Title: I Can't Make This Up: Life Lessons
Author: Kevin  Hart
My Review: Entertaining audio book, considering Kevin Hart is the narrator. It's the story of his life, growing up and becoming famous.

Title: American Kingpin: The Epic Hunt for the Criminal Mastermind Behind the Silk Road
Author: Nick Bilton
My Review: Great story about the FBI hunt for Ross Ulbricht

Title: Exponential Organizations: Why New Organizations Are Ten Times Better, Faster, Cheaper Than Yours (and What To Do About It)
Author: Salim Ismail

Title: Swarmwise
Author: Rick Falkvinge

Title: Hegemony How-To: A Roadmap for Radicals
Author: Jonathan Smucker

Title: Tools of Titans: The Tactics, Routines, and Habits of Billionaires, Icons, and World-Class Performers
Author: Timothy Ferriss

Title: The Starfish and the Spider: The Unstoppable Power of Leaderless Organizations
Author: Ori Brafman
My Review:
Interesting book. Unfortunately, the first chapter explained the concept, and the next 8 chapters were case studies from the early 2000's. Companies like Apache, eMule, Craiglist, eBay, etc. Hard to take a book seriously when eMule keeps getting brought up as a great case study.

You're better off reading the Wikipedia page: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Starfish_and_the_Spider

Title: Badass: Making Users Awesome
Author: Kathy Sierra
My Review:
It was a good book, but it's structured more like an extended comic book than a traditional Business book.

TL;DR: Make your users feel superhuman, and they'll tell all their friends about how awesome you are.

Title: The Inevitable: Understanding the 12 Technological Forces That Will Shape Our Future
Author: Kevin Kelly

Title: The Industries of the Future
Author: Alec J. Ross

Title: Al Franken, Giant of the Senate
Author: Al Franken
My Review:
I'd never heard of Al Franken before. I had heard a lot about this book recently, and since he was on SNL and now senator, I thought it would be a fun read.

The book is a great listen (Audible version is ready by Al Franken, so it's entertaining). For a book about politics, it was strange to laugh out loud awkwardly on the train multiple times.

Would recommend for anyone interested in how the US senate works, seen from the perspective of a former comedian.

Title: Love Does: Discover a Secretly Incredible Life in an Ordinary World
Author: Bob       Goff
My Review:
Two chapters in. "When I first found Jesus...".

*Mark as Finished
*Remove from device

Title: Digital Gold: Bitcoin and the Inside Story of the Misfits and Millionaires Trying to Reinvent Money
Author: Nathaniel Popper
My Review: Enjoyable read. Good balance of backstory, technical explanation and personality. Would recommend for anyone interested in bitcoin, the blockchain, or technology in general.

Title: Yes Please
Author: Amy Poehler
My Review: As a fan of Parks & Rec, this was fun and great to listen to. Not something I would recommend to someone who isn't an Amy Poehler fan.

Title: Inspired: How To Create Products Customers Love
Author: Marty Cagan

Title: High Output Management
Author: Andrew S. Grove
My Review:
This book is the grandfather of management books. From middle managers to C-level folks, this book provides very practical advice on everything needed to be a good manager.

Even though its written 30+ years ago, 99% of the content is timeless. Highly recommended as the first management book anyone should read.

Title: Console Wars: Sega, Nintendo, and the Battle that Defined a Generation
Author: Blake J. Harris
My Review:
Interesting to read about the history of Sega vs Nintendo as a user of both products, not realising the corporate interactions between the two.

Disappointing that it finishes in 96, when PS first launches and the Xbox <-> PS <-> Nintendo wars went down, but I guess thats for a different book.

Title: Dark Money: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right
Author: Jane Mayer
My Review:
As a foreigner looking into why the US political process is so crazy, this book was eye opening. Jane Mayer does a fantastic job investigating the money trail of Conservative 'think tanks'.

Would recommend to anyone as a great read, even those who find Politics boring.

Title: Judgment Calls: Twelve Stories of Big Decisions and the Teams That Got Them Right
Author: Thomas H. Davenport

Title: Superforecasting: The Art and Science of Prediction
Author: Philip E. Tetlock

Title: Spiritual Enterprise
Author: Lawrence M. Miller

Title: Managing Humans: Biting and Humorous Tales of a Software Engineering Manager
Author: Michael Lopp
My Review:
This book is filled interesting stories and anecdotes from the authors blog. I really enjoyed it reading it. It was both entertaining and insightful to hear the rants of an Engineering Manager. Since it's a collection of blog posts, the writing style is simple to read and the chapters are short, which makes it easy to digest and binge read.

4 stars instead of 5, because the last half is a bit too preachy and not as well structured as the first.

Title: The Israel Lobby and U.S. Foreign Policy
Author: John J. Mearsheimer

Title: Blueprint for Revolution: How to Use Rice Pudding, Lego Men, and Other Nonviolent Techniques to Galvanize Communities, Overthrow Dictators, or Simply Change the World
Author: Srdja Popovic

Title: Originals: How Non-Conformists Move the World
Author: Adam M. Grant
My Review:
I catagerize this into another "Gladwell-style" business book, without the high quality story telling that Gladwell uses. The book has annecdotal stories about entrepreneurs and famous people in history, and then recommends the principles that worked in a particular case (whether true or not) to the whole population as 'ways to be Original'.

Some things I took away:
1. Generate lots and lots of ideas. Constantly. It takes a lot of ideas to come up with the good ideas.
2. Beware of confirmation bias
3. Be a vocal devil’s advocates (aka the squeaky wheel)

Title: As One: Individual Action Collective Power
Author: Mehrdad Baghai

Title: The Best Place to Work: The Art and Science of Creating an Extraordinary Workplace
Author: Ron      Friedman
My Review:
An interesting overview of positive workplace behaviour. Unfortunately, there's a tonne of cliche'd statements and examples that sound good on the surface, but don't actually hold up to light when scrutinized.

It's like a Gladwell book about the workplace, without the excitement of a Gladwell book.

Title: The New Encyclopedia of Modern Bodybuilding
Author: Arnold Schwarzenegger
My Review:
This well and truly is The Bible of bodybuilding. Anyone considering spending more than an hour a week in the gym should get this book.

Read it once to get the gist, keep it forever as a reference book. I bought the Kindle version, but will probably get the physical version now to keep around.

Title: Start with Why: How Great Leaders Inspire Everyone to Take Action
Author: Simon Sinek
My Review:
All in all, the book had a good premise. Companies should have a purpose higher than the products it builds or the services it delivers. He uses few examples (Apple, MLK, Costco) and counter examples (Walmart, TiVo) to explain why 'starting with why' is important.

If there is a way for a book to be cringeworthy, this is it. The number of monumental statements about to brilliance of Apple were overwhelming. "The i at the beginning of their products isn't just part of name, it's the name itself". Easy tiger.

Would not recommend for people to read, see a summary instead.

Title: The Design of Everyday Things
Author: Donald A. Norman
My Review: This book was much longer and in depth than expected. For those that do power through it, it brings a unique design lens into anything you interact with on a day-to-day basis. From door handles to light switches, good and bad design is everywhere.

Title: Why Not Me?
Author: Mindy Kaling
My Review:
For a fan of the office, the book was a fun listen. The target demographic is most probably women, but considering it was actually her voice talking in the audiobook, it felt like a long standup show of hers.

Would recommend for people for an easy read.

Title: Alibaba: The House That Jack Ma Built
Author: Duncan Clark
My Review:
TL;DR: It's "The Everything Store", but for Alibaba.

For people interested in China, this book was a good insight into how things operate. The story didn't go into great depth. It was more a timeline history of Alibaba including its founding, funding, acquisitions/launches and finally IPO.

There isn't much drama, and there isn't a lot of insight into how Jack Ma operates the company.

Recommended read for people who don't know much about tech/ecommerce in China (i.e. myself)

Title: Whiplash: How to Survive Our Faster Future
Author: Joichi Ito

Title: Decisive: How to Make Better Choices in Life and Work
Author: Chip Heath

Title: The Undoing Project: A Friendship That Changed Our Minds
Author: Michael   Lewis
My Review:
Interesting insight into the origins and history of behaviroul economics. Amos and Kahnemann were an incredible pair of psychologists, and Lewis does a good job telling their story. It contains a mix of actual behaviroul content and the history of the pair.

Would recommend for folks who are interested in the field.

Title: The Swoly Bible: The Bro Science Way of Life
Author: Dom Mazzetti
My Review:
For those that follow BroScience on YouTube, this was a really entertaining book. I highly recommend the Audiobook version, as his voice is probably 80% of the comedy.

As mentioned in other reviews, a lot of the later chapters are copied from his videos. However it's still an enjoyable listen.

Title: The Hard Thing About Hard Things: Building a Business When There Are No Easy Answers―Straight Talk on the Challenges of Entrepreneurship
Author: Ben Horowitz
My Review: As someone who knew almost nothing about Ben Horowitz, DMX was not an opening line that I anticipated. The book is an enjoyable read, even though its pretty unrelated to day-to-day. If I were to ever become a founder of a tech startup, this book is a perfect resource for being a great wartime CEO.

Title: Michael Jordan: The Life
Author: Roland Lazenby

Title: Never Split the Difference: Negotiating As If Your Life Depended On It
Author: Chris Voss

Title: Negotiating the Nonnegotiable: How to Resolve Your Most Emotionally Charged Conflicts
Author: Daniel Shapiro

Title: Discussing Design: Improving Communication and Collaboration through Critique
Author: Adam Connor
My Review:
For people who work closely with designers, this book gives great practical advice on how to properly 'critique'.

The first half of the book is useful, while the second goes into granular details of some 9-5 basics, e.g. "be sure to take notes"

Would recommend for anyone who collaborates with designers sometimes, and mandatory for people who are responsible for designing (or approving designs) of user facing products.

Title: The Gene: An Intimate History
Author: Siddhartha Mukherjee

Title: String Theory: David Foster Wallace on Tennis
Author: David Foster Wallace

Title: Misbehaving: The Making of Behavioral Economics
Author: Richard H. Thaler
My Review:
I really enjoyed reading this book. It was a comprehensive read about Behavioral economics. Covering everything from confirmation bias, to sunk cost, to explaining the 'nudge' concept.

The only downside is that the book is very long, and spends a lot of time talking about the history (including the influencing individuals) behind a lot of the existing theories.

This book is the recommendation for "I know nothing about behavioral economics, where do i start?"

Title: Liar's Poker
Author: Michael   Lewis

Title: The Drama of the Gifted Child: The Search for the True Self
Author: Alice   Miller

Title: The Honest Truth About Dishonesty: How We Lie to Everyone - Especially Ourselves
Author: Dan Ariely
My Review:
Dan has one study that he manages to draw out to an entire book. This could have very easily been a long article and be just as impactful.

The content is interesting. Basically most humans tend to cheat, but mostly not maliciously.

It's a good read for people interested in human behaviors/psychology.

Title: Shoe Dog: A Memoir by the Creator of Nike
Author: Phil Knight
My Review:
What a fantastic read.

I originally thought that this was going to be about the logistics and growth of Nike as a brand. I was very wrong. This book is Phil Knights perspective on how Nike was born and bred for runners. Lot's of interesting characters, a lot of whom are now dead.

It's personal, reflective and rarely looks at the business aspects of the brand and products.

Title: Bossypants
Author: Tina Fey

Title: Everyday Zen: Love & Work
Author: Charlotte Joko Beck

Title: Fast Food Nation: The Dark Side of the All-American Meal
Author: Eric Schlosser

Title: Good Strategy Bad Strategy: The Difference and Why It Matters
Author: Richard P. Rumelt
My Review: TLDR: there is a difference between strategy, success metrics and goals. Strategy is what you do to achieve your goals, measured by your success metrics.

Title: Jony Ive: The Genius Behind Apple's Greatest Products
Author: Leander Kahney

Title: Naked Statistics: Stripping the Dread from the Data
Author: Charles Wheelan

Title: Delivering Happiness: A Path to Profits, Passion, and Purpose
Author: Tony Hsieh
My Review: Really insightful look at a company with an incredible corporate culture.

Title: Contagious: Why Things Catch On
Author: Jonah Berger
My Review:
This book is perfect for anyone getting into marketing for this first time, and wants a 101 on Content and 'Viral' marketing

The examples used are from viral videos in the late 2000's and very early 2010's. It's hard to take a book seriously when what is written in this book is now commonplace through the internet.

A 2-page TL;DR or 20-slide presentation, would have been a perfect way to digest this instead of reading the entire book. The introduction actually does a pretty good job of doing that.

The entire book revolves around STEPPS, which stands for:

Social currency
Triggers
Emotion
Public
Practical Value
Stories

One sentence summaries of each of the above, and you're done.

Title: My Story
Author: Steven Gerrard

Title: Carra: My Autobiography
Author: Jamie Carragher

Title: I am not a salesperson: Succeed in sales by being you
Author: Sana Vasli

Title: Made to Stick: Why Some Ideas Survive and Others Die
Author: Chip Heath

Title: The Upside of Irrationality: The Unexpected Benefits of Defying Logic at Work and at Home
Author: Dan Ariely

Title: I Am Not A Salesperson: Succeed in sales by being you
Author: Sana Vasli

Title: The Lean Startup
Author: Eric Ries

Title: The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business
Author: Charles Duhigg

Title: The Effective Executive: The Definitive Guide to Getting the Right Things Done (Harperbusiness Essentials)
Author: Peter F. Drucker

Title: Zero to One: Notes on Startups, or How to Build the Future
Author: Peter Thiel

Title: The Tipping Point: How Little Things Can Make a Big Difference
Author: Malcolm Gladwell

Title: David and Goliath: Underdogs, Misfits, and the Art of Battling Giants
Author: Malcolm Gladwell

Title: The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business
Author: Charles Duhigg

Title: The Innovator's DNA: Mastering the Five Skills of Disruptive Innovators
Author: Jeffrey H. Dyer
Additional Authors: Hal B. Gregersen, Clayton M. Christensen

Title: Predictably Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions
Author: Dan Ariely

Title: Hatching Twitter: A True Story of Money, Power, Friendship, and Betrayal
Author: Nick Bilton

Title: Flash Boys: A Wall Street Revolt
Author: Michael   Lewis

Title: The Good Jobs Strategy: How the Smartest Companies Invest in Employees to Lower Costs and Boost Profits
Author: Zeynep Ton

Title: How Google Works
Author: Eric Schmidt

Title: Start Something That Matters
Author: Blake Mycoskie

Title: Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time
Author: Jeff Sutherland

Title: Creativity, Inc.: Overcoming the Unseen Forces That Stand in the Way of True Inspiration
Author: Ed Catmull

Title: The Everything Store: Jeff Bezos and the Age of Amazon
Author: Brad Stone

Title: Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products
Author: Nir   Eyal

Title: When to Rob a Bank: ...And 131 More Warped Suggestions and Well-Intended Rants
Author: Steven D. Levitt

Title: Turn The Ship Around!: How to Create Leadership at Every Level
Author: L. David Marquet

Title: Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking
Author: Malcolm Gladwell

Title: Outliers: The Story of Success
Author: Malcolm Gladwell

Title: The E-myth Revisited
Author: Michael E. Gerber

Title: The First 90 Days: Critical Success Strategies for New Leaders at All Levels
Author: Michael D. Watkins

Title: The 48 Laws of Power
Author: Robert Greene

Title: Buyology: Truth and Lies About Why We Buy
Author: Martin Lindstrom

Title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
Author: Daniel Kahneman

Title: How We Decide
Author: Jonah Lehrer

Title: No Logo
Author: Naomi Klein

Author: Timothy Ferriss

Author: Andre Agassi

Author: Walter Isaacson
